WinTieLoss 0.1.0

Plot Win-Tie-Loss Barplot

win.tie.loss.plot.Rd

This function generates a barplot visualizing the win-tie-loss summary for different methods. The resulting plot provides a clear graphical representation of the performance of various methods in terms of wins, ties, and losses. The plot is saved as a PDF file.

win.tie.loss.plot(
  data,
  names.methods,
  name.file,
  max.value,
  width,
  height,
  bottom,
  left,
  top,
  right,
  size.font,
  wtl
)

Arguments

data

A data frame containing the win-tie-loss summary, where each row corresponds to a method, and each column corresponds to the counts of wins, ties, and losses.

names.methods

A vector of method names to be displayed along the y-axis of the plot.

name.file

The name of the output PDF file, including the path where the file will be saved.

max.value

A numeric value indicating the maximum limit for the x-axis. This should correspond to the highest value of the win-tie-loss counts for proper visualization.

width

The width of the plot in inches.

height

The height of the plot in inches.

bottom

Margin size (in lines) for the bottom of the plot.

left

Margin size (in lines) for the left of the plot.

top

Margin size (in lines) for the top of the plot.

right

Margin size (in lines) for the right of the plot.

size.font

Font size for labels, method names, and axis text.

wtl

A character vector indicating the labels for the respective categories: wins, ties, and losses. Default is `c("win", "tie", "loss")`.

Value

A PDF file containing the win-tie-loss barplot saved at the specified location. The plot includes a legend and reference lines to aid in interpretation.

Examples

# Define the file path and read the data
name.file <- "~/WinTieLoss/Data/clp.csv"
data <- read.csv(name.file)
#> Warning: cannot open file 'C:/Users/Cissa/Documents/WinTieLoss/Data/clp.csv': No such file or directory
#> Error in file(file, "rt"): cannot open the connection
data <- data[,-1]  # Remove the first column if not needed
#> Error in data[, -1]: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

# Get method names from the data frame
methods.names <- colnames(data)

# Calculate win-tie-loss measures
df_res.mes <- wtl.measures()
filtered_res.mes <- filter(df_res.mes, names == "clp")
#> Error in names == "clp": comparison (==) is possible only for atomic and list types
measure.type <- as.numeric(filtered_res.mes$type)
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'filtered_res.mes' not found

# Compute win-tie-loss summary
res <- win.tie.loss.compute(data = data, measure.type)
#> Warning: is.na() applied to non-(list or vector) of type 'closure'
#> Error in data[is.na(data)] <- 0: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable
res$method <- factor(res$method, levels = methods.names)
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'res' not found
res <- res[order(res$method), ]
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'res' not found

# Save results to CSV
save <- paste(FolderResults, "/clp.csv", sep="")
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'FolderResults' not found
write.csv(res, save, row.names = FALSE)
#> Error in eval(expr, p): object 'res' not found

# Define win-tie-loss labels
wtl <- c("win", "tie", "loss")
colnames(res) <- wtl 
#> Error: object 'res' not found

# Generate and save the barplot
save <- paste(FolderResults, "/clp.pdf", sep="")
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'FolderResults' not found
win.tie.loss.plot(data = res, 
                  names.methods = methods.names, 
                  name.file = save, 
                  max.value = 600,  # Set the maximum x-axis value
                  width = 18, 
                  height = 10, 
                  bottom = 2, 
                  left = 11, 
                  top = 0, 
                  right = 1, 
                  size.font = 2.0, 
                  wtl = wtl)
#> Error in win.tie.loss.plot(data = res, names.methods = methods.names,     name.file = save, max.value = 600, width = 18, height = 10,     bottom = 2, left = 11, top = 0, right = 1, size.font = 2,     wtl = wtl): unused argument (max.value = 600)
